FacilityName: City Of Ashland Waste Water Treatment Plant

Executive Summary

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Operation is committed to providing the optimum in employee and public safety and health. It is our policy that each employee has a safe healthful place in which to work. It is also the policy of the City of Ashland to expect each employee to live up to the responsibility of following all safety rules and committing to safety. The City of Ashland will coordinate adequate emergency response capabilities to handle any on site emergency regarding RMP-covered chemicals. The City of Ashland executes this policy through employee training, education, coordination and drills with local emergency response agencies.

Facility Description

The basic concept of disinfection of waste streams with chlorine depends on its solution in water. Dissolving chlorine in water rapidly forms a mixture of hypochlorous acid and hydrochloric acid which is a pH dependent reaction. Dissociation of hypochlorous acid increases as pH increases from 6.0 to 8.5.  Chlorine exists predominantly as hypochlorous acid. Chlorine existing in the forms of hypochlorous acid and the hypochlorite ion is defined as ?free chlorine.? Chlorine may react with certain components in the wastewater to impair its efficiency as a disinfectant.  Dechlorination is achieved through the use of sulfur dioxide gas which, when dissolved in water forms sulfurous acid, a strong reducing agent.  Chemically, sulfur dioxide, when added to chlorinated water, reduces all forms of free chlorine to chloride and is converted itself   in to sulfate. Both chlorides and sulfates occur naturally in most waters.  Sulfonation removes free and combined residuals with equal efficiency.

The chlorinators original flow control was proportional. They are now manually adjusted by using the total chlorine results in conjunction with the fecal coliform results supplied by the lab.  The chlorine system is able to feed 360 lbs. per day which is seven times higher than our normal feed rate of around

50 lbs. per day. The sulfur dioxide rate is set at approximatly120 lbs. feed to insure an adequate kill to the residual chlorine.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide containers are used in the order received and are stored separately from the empty containers.  Each cylinder is checked with aqueous ammonia as it comes off the truck to insure there are no leaks before the delivery is accepted.
 
The maximum inventory of chlorine stored in one- ton cylinders and connected at the unloading station into the system at one time is 4000 lbs. Only one cylinder (2,000 lbs) is being utilized at any given time. The maximum inventory of sulfur dioxide and chlorine in one-ton cylinders including storage is 8,000 lbs for each.

Deviations from the normal procedures involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide could easily cause the malfunction or destruction of equipment, Injury or loss of life.  Further a catastrophic release of gas would cause the evacuation of nearby residents and could affect the water quality of downstream users if the disinfection process were to be interrupted. 

Procedures are in place for connecting, changing and valving one ton chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders into the process.

In the event of the sulfur dioxide pump malfunction there is in place a water feed system that will disburse the sulfur dioxide to the effluent water in a liquid suspension rather than direct injection by gas.  To initiate this procedure the sulfur pump is removed and the valve is changed to facilitate the flow of gas through a pipe supply system. The water feed system is turned on to produce a vacuum for the system. The gas feeds from the tank as normal. There are no temporary conditions required for the chlorine system.  Each part of the system can be isolated and rerouted so that part of the system can be worked on while as a whole the process continues to operate. Should repairs not allow for this the system must be shut down and Emergency Procedures are in place.

f Hazards


Chlorine:

Chlorine (CL2) at ambient temperature and pressure is a light greenish-yellow gas. Each molecule of chlorine contains 2 atoms of chlorine. It is heavier than air and extremely toxic with 8 hour exposure limits of 1PPM. It has a strong pungent smell that serves as a warning of its presence. Chlorine is an extremely strong oxidizing agent and is commonly used as a disinfectant in potable water and waste water systems.
Chlorine is toxic by inhalation, ingestion and through skin contact. Inhalation can cause serious lung damage and may be fatal.
The DOT classifies chlorine as a corrosive and toxic material.

Sulfur Dioxide

Sulfur dioxide (SO2) at ambient temperature and pressure is a colorless gas. Each molecule of sulfur dioxide contains 1 atom of sulfur and 2 atoms of oxygen. It is heavier than air and extremely toxic with 8 hour exposure limits of 2 PPM. It has a strong pungent smell that serves as a warning of its presence. Sulfur dioxide is a bi product from ore smelting and is an interim product in the production of sulfuric acid. It is also used in waste water treatment and potable water treatment to control residual chlorine levels.  Sulfur dioxide is corrosive when wet.
The DOT classifies sulfur dioxide as toxic.

Worst Case Release Scenario

The two worst case scenarios for the City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility involve a rupture of either a Chlorine Cylinder or a Sulfur Dioxide cylinder resulting in a total loss of the contents over a ten minute period. This has the potential to impact public receptors in the area that includes schools, public parks, hospitals, residential areas and commercial buildings. 


Alternate Case Release Scenario

The Alternate Case Release Scenarios for the City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility were chosen to be a rupture in the gas delivery lines for either the Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide Systems.  This has potential to impact public receptors in the area that includes residential areas and commercia

l buildings. 

Process Safety Information

Process Safety Information (PSI) relating to the covered processes resides in several forms. PSI relating to chemical hazards is included in the MSDS?s that are kept in readily accessible locations for all employees. PSI relating to the process technology is generally indicated on process drawings, and is referenced in applicable operating procedures and engineering files. PSI relating to process equipment is located in the Maintenance office.

Process Hazards Analysis

Process Hazard Analyses are conducted as a method of recognizing safety, health and environmental issues that are potentially dangerous. Equipment in the processes and alarms has been upgraded as a result of risk recognition methodologies being applied at the facility. A Process Hazard Analyses is scheduled to occur in September 2004. 

Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures for the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide processes are current and accurate. Procedures exist for the safe handling, transportation, hook up and changing of cylinders. The current procedures reside in the control room and are available to the employees.

Training

The City of Ashland provides on the job training and classroom training to employees responsible for operating the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide systems. The trainees must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the supervisor that they possess the skills and knowledge to perform the required duties prior to being assigned operations responsibilities. Refresher training on the operating procedures is provided at a minimum of every three years. Hazard communication and chemical training are provided to each maintenance and operations employee on an annual basis.

Mechanical Integrity

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility performs inspections, tests and maintenance of pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems (including valves), relief and vent system devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, alarms and interlo

cks. Tests and inspections follow applicable and acceptable codes and standards at a frequency called for by the OEM information from the vendors / suppliers, or more frequently if needed. Maintenance employees are trained on the acceptable work practices relating to the inspection and testing requirements. Refresher training is provided to maintenance employees on acceptable work practices relating to the inspection, testing and maintenance requirements.

Management of Change

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Operations has a Management Of Change (MOC) procedure that ensures that proposed changes to the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide systems address: the technical basis of the proposed change; the impact on environment, health and safety; modifications to operating procedures; the time period of the change and the authorization requirements for the proposed change. The procedure also addresses employee training and updating of process safety information.

Pre Start up Safety Review

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Operation has a Pre Start up Safety Review (PSSR) procedure. The procedure confirms that prior to the introduction of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide to new or modified equipment: construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency response procedures are in place; the MOC requirements have been met; a process hazards analysis has been performed, if necessary, and employees have been properly trained.

Compliance Audits

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Operation has conducted compliance audits in the past. A schedule is established and a compliance audit to measure the PSM and RMP requirements will take place by December 2004. The audit will consist of a records review, evaluation of on site conditions and interviews with employees. The audit will be conducted by an independent consulting company.

Incident Investigation

Incident investigations are conducted for each incident that result

in or could potentially result in a catastrophic release of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide. Investigation teams are comprised of representatives from safety, maintenance, production and any other affected groups (e.g. contractors). Investigations are initiated within 48 hours of the incident. Incident investigation reports contain at a minimum: date of incident, description of the incident, investigation team members, factors contributing to the incident and the recommended corrective actions. Management will review open corrective actions on a regular basis to ensure they receive a high priority for accomplishment.

Employee Participation

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility actively encourages employee participation at all levels of development, implementation and maintenance of the RMP program.

Hot Work Permit

The Hot Work Permit System covers such items as: appropriate fire protection, fire watch requirements, time frame for work to be conducted, equipment to be worked on, the individual responsible for the work and approval of the work.

Contractors

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility has 24 hour security provided. A monitored security gate system requiring identification is attended at the main entrance 24 hours per day. Contractors must stop at the main gate and be cleared for entry. The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility has developed a contractor approval procedure that ensures the contractor safety record is considered during the contractor selection process. Additionally, The City of Ashland has developed a program to ensure that all contractors receive appropriate training on the hazards of Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide prior to working at the facility.

Five Year Accident History

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Operations has not had an accident involving a release of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide in the past five years. No accidents have occurred that resulted in offsite consequences, no onsite or offsite deaths and no injuries

or property damage. Evacuation of the facility has not been required and no exposures occurred on site.

Emergency Response Program

The City of Ashland Waste Treatment Facility is considered to be a non responding facility under 40 CFR Part 68.90. The City of Ashland has developed a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan that includes coordination with the appropriate local agencies. Employees are trained in emergency response as it pertains to small spills or releases.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

RMP program policies and procedures are scheduled to be revised and updated by September 2004. A Process Hazards Analysis is scheduled to be conducted by September 2004. An integrated PSM / RMP Audit is scheduled to be completed by December 2004.
